newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: Asian natural gas demand seen doubling by 2006.
newsitem.headline: Asian natural gas demand seen doubling by 2006.

text.p: Asian petrochemical demand for natural gas is expected to rise to 40 billion cubic metres a year over the next 10 years from a 18 billion cubic metres now, a senior Pertamina official said on Wednesday.
G.A.S. Nayoan, a senior executive vice president on the $40 billion Natuna offshore gas project, said the spectrum of gas use would widen as Asia's economies grow.
He was speaking at the Asian International Refining, LNG and Petrochemical Conference which started in Singapore on Wednesday.
Natural gas is currently used as a fuel for electricity generation.
But Nayoan said he expected the gas to become increasingly important to the chemical industry, which he expected to grow six to seven percent annually.
"The growth would challenge natural gas as a feedstock rather than being used as, for example, a fuel," he said.

Nayoan said the future use of natural gas was dominated by the need to find a way to process carbon dioxide into a marketable product. Carbon dioxide often represents the biggest portion of a natural gas field.
But he said advances in technology to allow processing of carbon dioxide was a priority.

"The existence of 71 percent of carbon dioxide, for example, in the Natuna project's gas stream, could perhaps be converted from a burden into an economical opportunity, by means of processing," he told the conference.
The 46 trillion cubic feet Natuna field in the South China Sea is expected to produce 480 million standard square feet of liquefied natural gas per day by 2002.
Nayoan said 60 percent of the cost of the project involved dealing with waste gas and then reinjecting it under the field to maintain the field's pressure.
